links.title: Use Statements and Propositions.

links.description: This subsection should introduce all 5 Boolean connectors (\( \neg \), \( \wedge \), \( \vee \), \( \rightarrow \), \( \leftrightarrow \)), their truth tables.

tasks.description: Mention non-proposition sentences, include trickier situations (contradictory self-referential statements)
tasks.title: Define what is a proposition

tasks.description: Define Boolean operations through its natural language equivalent and its truth table.
tasks.title: Define Boolean operations (\( \neg, \wedge, \vee, \rightarrow, \leftrightarrow \))

tasks.description: Show how to evaluate expressions starting from subexpressions by plugging in the True/False values.
tasks.title: Create truth tables for expressions

tasks.description: Explain that power operation (\( 2^{3^4} \)) as well as the logical implication (\( A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C \)) are right-associative - they group from the right to the left.
tasks.title: Introduce the formal concepts of precedence and associativity.

tasks.description: Show that Boolean expressions is one specific case of expressions (along with arithmetic, polynomials, etc.) May also illustrate precedence (arithmetic, comparisons, Booleans) in some programming language.
tasks.title: Restore parentheses in a Boolean expression using precedence (e.g. negation has the highest priority, conjunction is done before disjunction). Draw syntax trees showing evaluation order.

links.title: Analyze Propositions and Boolean Expressions

links.description: Solve some word problems with propositional logic. We should pay special attention to cases where the connectors can be misunderstood or their everyday meaning differs from the formal one.

tasks.description: Given a statement in English and atomic propositions, write its Boolean expression.
tasks.title: Translate English into Propositional logic.

tasks.description: Analyze phrases expressing inclusive and exclusive OR; various ways to express implications (“sufficient”, “necessary”, “whenever”, “if”, “only if”, “if and only if”)
tasks.title: Recognize situations when natural language uses logical connectives in a different sense.

tasks.description: Use case analysis and other simple methods to establish truth values of propositions, if some incomplete information about the situation is given.
tasks.title: Solve Logic Puzzles and Word Problems based on propositional logic

tasks.description: Apply short-circuit Boolean evaluation in some programming language such as Python. Lazy and eager evaluation (and distinguishing them by side-effects). Explain how "if” statements differ from implications in propositional calculus.
tasks.title: Use Boolean expressions in programming.

links.title: Create propositional statements

links.description:
Perform equivalent transformations of Boolean expressions (here we use equivalences not as Boolean connectors that may sometimes return “False”, but as a way to write Boolean identities that are universaly true). 
Also solve satisfiablility of Boolean problems in a more general sense - even when they are not equivalences.

tasks.description: Tasks may include other manipulations on truth tables (building jus the "interesting" parts of tables; finding which values must take certain values)
tasks.title: Check tautologies using truth tables

tasks.description: Simplify Boolean statements using Boolean identities (double negation; De Morgan's laws; Contrapositive for an Implication; distributive laws and so on)
tasks.title: Rewrite propositions using equivalences

tasks.description: Describe tautologies, satisfiable expressions and contradictions in terms of truth tables. Prove or disprove Boolean tautologies; check satisfiability of Boolean expressions. In all these situations try to pare down the truth tables to find "interesting" subcases to check (get used to avoid mechanistical approach to verify all 2^n rows in a truth table as this would be error-prone and slow).
tasks.title: Identify tautologies, satisfiable statements and contradictions

tasks.description: Use syllogisms like Modus Ponens and other inference rules to derive logical formulas.
tasks.title: Create new tautologies from existing ones using inference rules.

tasks.description: Use truth table to construct CNF or DNF; make it shorter by combining similar terms.
tasks.title: Convert every Boolean expression to its CNF and DNF

tasks.description: Draw Boolean circuits where you are allowed to reuse the same subexpression output in multiple inputs.
tasks.title: Draw a Boolean circuit, try to use limited number of elements.

links.title: Identify tautologies, contradictions and satisfiable expressions

links.description: This subsection introduces predicates as expressions depending on variables and "naive" concept of quantifiers (universal quantifier is just a long conjunction; existential quantifier is just a long disjunction)

tasks.description: Interpret commonly known math concepts (inequalities, relations in geometry) as predicates.
tasks.title: Define a predicate as a function to booleans.

tasks.description: Draw syntax trees, define scopes of variables, recognize free and bound variables.
tasks.title: Analyze syntax and restore parentheses in quantifier expressions.

tasks.description: Given value table for some predicate on a finite domain, evaluate quantifier expressions.
tasks.title: Interpret quantifiers over finite domains as long conjunction (\( \forall \)) or long disjunction (\( \exists \))

tasks.description: Use precedence rules, restore parentheses, avoid ambiguities with set domains.
tasks.title: Check the syntax in quantifier expressions

tasks.description: Negate predicates applying De Morgan's laws.
tasks.title: Apply simple manipulations to predicate/quantifier expressions (apply negations, rename variables, apply other tautologies).

links.title: Use Predicates and Quantifiers

links.description: This section does not cover much new material; it is useful as a reminder - how to use the first order logic to explain everyday situations.

tasks.description: Formalize English sentences and some mathematical statements into propositional logic and simple (1st order; no more than 2 nesting levels) predicate calculus.
tasks.title: Rewrite English sentences and mathematical statements with nested quantifiers.
Interpret quantifier expressions in human language (Show the difference between "For every person there exists a father" vs. "There exists a father for everyone")

Negate multiple quantifiers using De Morgan's laws and other equivalence rules.Evaluate Boolean expressions (and also predicate/quantifier expressions over simple or finite sets). May need to introduce simple relations (square tables with True/False) to illustrate how predicates/quantifiers operate.
Rewrite popular mathematical concepts (divisibility, being a prime number, monotonicity, boundedness, continuity, existence of a limit, existence of a derivative) with predicates and quantifiers

links.title: Use Nested Quantifiers

links.description: This section is meant to introduce some Aristotelian and other traditional logic reasoning (modus ponens, substitution, etc.) and other rules of inference. Only simple cases are shown; we do not show the tricky cases of inference; do not differentiate between constructive and non-constructive logic at this point.

tasks.title: Recognize hypotheses and goals in a proof.
Apply modus ponens: \( A \rightarrow B,\, A \;\vdash\; B \)
Apply modus tollens: \( A \rightarrow B,\, (\neg B) \;\vdash\; (\neg A) \)
Apply transitivity: \( A \rightarrow B,\, B \rightarrow C \;\vdash\; A \rightarrow C \)
Apply disjunctive syllogism: \( A \vee B,\, \neg A \;\vdash\; B \)
Apply "addition": \( A \;\vdash\; A \vee B \)
Apply "simplification": \( (A \wedge B) \;\vdash\; A \)
Apply "conjunction": \( A,\, B \;\vdash\; (A \wedge B) \)
Apply "resolution": \( (A \vee B),\, (\neg A \vee C) \;\vdash\; (B \vee C) \)

links.title: Use Rules of Inference

videos.title: Rules of Inference for Propositional Logic
Rules of Inference for Quantified Statements

links.description: This subsection should introduce the basics of human-readable proofs with simple logical structure (and without overly complicated mathematics). We illustrate IF-THEN and IF-AND-ONLY-IF types of statements with results from elementary geometry, algebra, number theory or real analysis. (It is highly desirable to choose examples that may be familiar to the participants.)

tasks.title: Explain direct proofs for IF-THEN statements
Explain proofs by contraposition for IF-THEN statements

Explain constructive proofs by contradiction (e.g. non-existence). Simple examples that show how proofs by contradiction do not need to rely on the classical logic (such as the Law of Excluded Middle)

links.title: Use Common Proof Strategies

links.description: Introduce proof techniques that reflect simple logical structure of the statement (for example analyzing cases would mean a generalization/universal quantifier over some finite set of cases;

tasks.title: Explain proofs by analyzing cases.
Explain proofs by counterexamples.
Introduce "without loss of generality" clauses.

Explain nonconstructive proofs by contradiction (e.g. existence). Game analysis by "mirroring strategy" and other proofs that look somewhat like cheating, but are actually correct. Why the Law of Excluded Middle is necessary in such cases.

links.title: Use More Proof Strategies

objectives: Create simple human-readable proofs by cases/by exhaustion.
Create simple human-readable proofs "by contradiction".
Distinguish one-way (implication) proofs and two-way (equivalence) proofs.
Distinguish universal statements (about every element in some set) and the counterexample proofs (refute a universal statement by some unusual example).
title: 2022-01-11 to 2022-01-15

links.title: Define Sets, Functions, their Set-Level Properties

links.description: This subsection only cares about set notation, defining new sets via subset and tuple (pair, tripple, etc.) constructions.

tasks.title: Define set by listing elements or intervals.
Define set by defining a predicate.
Define subsets, proper subsets.
Define pairs and other n-tuples.
Define power sets.
Reproduce Russel's paradox and retell it in some situations.
Demonstrate how predicate logic statements depend on the set used as the domain for quantifiers.

links.title: Manipulate Sets and Functions

links.description: This subsection is a refresher of the Boolean operations, since set operations for a given universe closely resemble Boolean operations (set intersection is same as conjunction, etc.)

tasks.title: Define the union of two or more sets.
Define the intersection of two or more sets.
Define the complement of a set.
Define the difference of two sets.
Define the symmetric difference of sets.
Draw Venn diagrams for 2, 3, 4 sets.
Draw Euler diagrams (where some subset relations are known - so you do not show all the \( 2^n \) theoretically possible regions as in a Venn diagram).

links.title: Manipulate sets over some universe

links.description: Nearly every topic in mathematics is somehow related to functions; here we only explain some set-theoretical properties of functions - defining domain, range, some properties (one-to-one, onto, bijection), also inverse and composition of two or more functions.

tasks.title: Describe the domain and the range (codomain) of a function.
Describe the one-to-one, onto and bijective (i.e. one-to-one AND onto) properties of a function.
Find inverse functions for some known function examples
Find composition of multiple functions.

links.title: Define functions and their set-related properties

videos.title: One to One and Onto Functions
Inverse Functions and Composition of Functions

objectives: Create proofs showing that some 2 sets are different (find a conterexample or use some non-constructive approach).
Explain proofs for a function being bijective or injective.
Explain proofs and constructions by selecting an extreme element in a set.
Use set notation with a predicate (create a subset of a given set - all elements satisfying some property); use set notation for n-tuples, for finite sequences.

Use function and set notation to describe functions with the given domain and range; use the notation of an inverse function $f^{-1}$ and the composition of two functions. Also the image and the inverse image of some set w.r.t. some function.
title: 2022-01-18 to 2022-01-22

links.description: This subsection introduces simple sequences and also notation (long sums, products, Boolean operations, set unions/intersections) to manipulate them.

tasks.title: Define sequences as functions from natural numbers to something
Define recurrent sequences
Define long sums and similar looping constructs

links.title: Define and use sequences

links.description: This subsection discusses comparing sizes of two sets; it is essential to develop intuition on which problems can be formalized and which ones are algorithmically solvable.

tasks.title: Define injective functions between 2 sets.
Define surjective functions between 2 sets.
Prove that adding finitely many elements to a countable set is countable
Prove that the union of two countable sets is countable
Prove that the union of countably many countable sets is countable
Prove that the powerset of any set is larger than the original set
Prove statements about subsets, functions, sequences in the set of integers
Set cardinality results in geometry (2D space has the same number of points as a 1D space). Continuum hypothesis.
Apply Schroder-Bernstein theorem to show that bijection must exist.

links.title: Compare Set Cardinalities

videos.title: Integers and Rationals are both infinite but is it the SAME infinity?

links.description: Matrices are rectangular tables of objects of some kind (usually numbers or truth values); this subsection shows how they can be used to describe functional dependencies between elements in two sets - e.g. linear transformations; directed graphs; relations on a given set - all these situations will need them. At this point it is just an introduction for the matrix notation and some simple manipulations on them.

tasks.title: Perform sum, difference, product of numeric matrices
Define join (memberwise disjunction), meet (entry-by-entry conjunction) and the Boolean product of two matrices.
Define transposed matrices, symmetric matrices.

links.title: Perform actions on matrices with discrete objects

objectives: Define which sets are countable; how they can be enumerated and encoded in a computer's memory. (Consider finite sequences of integers; infinite sequences of integers; computable infinite sequences of integers; various sets of functions between certain sets)
title: 2022-01-25 to 2022-01-29

links.title: Identify algorithms and estimate their time complexity

links.description: In the subsection we introduce various concepts related to algorithms: input, output, pseudocode, execution time, underlying variables and data, proofs of correctness.

tasks.title: Describe common characteristics of algorithms (mass problem, input, output, strictly defined steps, finite time)
Describe an algorithm to find maximum in a list of n with pseudocode.
Describe linear search algorithm
Describe binary search algorithm
Describe bubble sort algorithm
Describe the naive string matching algorithm
Describe the greedy algorithm to pay the change with minimum coins.
Prove that for the eurocent coins (1,2,5,10,20,50,100,200) greedy algorithm is optimal
Describe the greedy scheduling algorithm
Define the halting problem; prove that it is unsolvable

links.title: Describe algorithms for lists/arrays and their paradigms

videos.title: Introduction to Algorithms and Pseudo Code

links.description: This subsection is preoccupied by the growth asymtotics, it introduces various growth rates (Big-O-Notation) and also the related Omega and Theta notations.

readings.title: Total Noobs Guide to Big O

tasks.title: Define the big-O notation
Compare various elementary functions by their growth speed
Compute the big-O for sums and products of functions.
Define big-Omega and big-Theta notations
Produce graphs (in xOy plane) or tables for some functions to compare their growth

links.title: Define and use the big-O notation and related complexity measures

links.description: This subsection combines two previous ones – we analyze the pseudocode of an algorithm and come up with an estimate of how many operations it takes (up to a constant factor and addition with terms of smaller growth order).

tasks.title: Define time and space complexity for the given run of a program
Define worst-case and average time complexity
Describe the number of steps for binary search in a list of n elements
Compute the number of steps for bubble sort
Compute the lower bound for any sorting algorithm
Compute the number of steps for naive string matching
Develop an intuition about function growth rates
Analyze some Fibonacci computation algorithms (avoid cases where recursive calls multiply exponentially)

links.title: Define and determine some algorithm complexity measures

objectives: Compare two functions in terms of their asymptotic growth; find their location in the growth hierarchy.
Given a pseudocode of an algorithm (and assumptions about the speed of its data-structure calls) find its time complexity in terms of its input length.
For problems like sorting, searching, some number manipulations offer an optimal algorithm or analyze, if the proposed algorithm is efficient enough.
title: 2022-02-01 to 2022-02-05

links.title: Use modular arithmetic

links.description: This subtopic only focuses on modular arithmetic (properties that are preserved when finding remainders during division by a fixed positive integer \( m \)).

tasks.title: Add, subtract and multiply congruences (ring operations)
Transform congurences equivalently

links.title: Operate with modular arithmetic

links.description: In this subsection we convert decimal to binary and similar numbering systems.

tasks.title: Convert a representation of a number into a number by Horner’s scheme
Obtain a representation of a number by Horner’s scheme backwards
Perform arithmetic operations on number representations
Make computations on binary fractions (including infinite periodic fractions)
Perform efficient modular exponentiation

links.title: Convert integer representations

videos.title: Conversion Between Binary, Octal and Hexadecimal Expansions

links.description: This subtopic introduces algorithms related to primality, divisibility and finding GCD or LCM.

tasks.title: Analyze the full search primality testing algorithm (divide up to \( \sqrt{n} \))
Prove that there are infinitely many primes
State known facts about prime “gaps”
State properties of LCD and GCD
Apply Euclid algorithm to compute LCD

links.title: Prove properties of primes, GCD, LCM and related algorithms

links.description: Show how to solve linear congruences (or systems of linear congruences as in the Chinese Remainder theorem)

tasks.title: Use Blankinship algorithm to compute Bezout coefficients
Find inverse of a number w.r.t. some module
Solve arbitrary linear congruences
Prove and use Chinese remainder theorem
Prove and use Little Fermat theorem
Formulate and use Euler's theorem
Solve problems with primitive roots and discrete logarithms

links.title: Find Bezout coefficients and solve linear congruences

links.description: The only subsection on the applications of number theory focuses on algorithms to compute hash functions and also the checksums designed to ensure the integrity of data. (There are other major applications, say, in cryptography, but we do not care, since the course has sufficiently large scope already.)

tasks.title: Define a simple hashing function using modular arithmetic
Define some popular checksums using modular arithmetic
Check the integrity of credit cards, personal identity numbers ("personas kods", Latvia) and ISBN.

links.title: Define hashing and checksums in terms of modular arithmetic

objectives: Do addition, subtraction and multiplication on congruences
Do efficient raising to powers on congruences (apply Euler's theorem, if needed)
Run Euclid's algorithm to find GCD
Solve linear congruences, convert word problems into linear congruences
Perform Luhn check, ISBN check and some similar checksum tests
Convert to binary, hexadecimal, octal and back.
title: 2022-02-08 to 2022-02-12

links.title: Prove statements by mathematical induction

links.description: This subsection explains the very basic scheme of induction (prove the statement for \( n=0 \) or \( n=1 \), then prove it by advancing one step at a time).

tasks.title: Prove summation formulas and other algebraic identities by induction
Prove inequalities by induction
Use the method of invariants to prove impossibility results

links.title: Prove general statements using the simplest scheme of mathematical induction (\( n \rightarrow n+1 \))

videos.title: Mathematical Induction - Summation Formulae and Inequalities
Mathematical Induction - Divisibility and Set Theory

links.description: Define and prove statements by induction, where it is essential to look back more than one step.

tasks.title: Introduce hot and cold states in combinatorial games.
Analyze winning strategies in some games using strong induction
Prove formulas for recurrent sequences (such as Fibonacci) by using modified scheme of induction.

links.title: Prove statements by variants of mathematical induction

videos.title: The Well Ordering Principle and Strong Induction

links.description: Define and prove inductive statements that can be defined on expressions and/or tree-like structures.

tasks.title: Define sequences recursively (Fibonacci, Catalan, etc.) and illustrate them in word problems.
Define tree-like structures recursively (next level in a tree is created from multiple subtrees)
Define syntax trees (for expressions, statements) in programming language
Introduce attributes that are calculated as we move up the tree
Define simple fractals using Lindenmayer systems

links.title: Use recursive definitions and structural induction

objectives: Prove general statements (predicates on the set of natural numbers) using mathematical induction
Explain proofs using invariants showing impossibility (some property holds at the beginning; then various transformations are applied that preserve that invariant; so it must hold at the end)
Prove some recurrent equalities (closed formulas for recurrent sequences) using mathematical induction
Create trees using production rules (like in Lindenmayer systems, formal grammars, etc.), evaluate attributes on these trees.
title: 2022-02-15 to 2022-02-19

links.title: Introduce relations, their properties and possible representations.

links.description: This subsection only discusses binary relations at a general level.

tasks.title: Define general binary relations on \( A \times B \) and on \( A \times A \).
Identify properties for relations; check them in examples.
Combine relations into new ones.

links.title: Define and analyze binary relations

links.description: The subsection adresses somewhat marginal topic of n-ary relations, but it is still important, since it forms the basis of relational databases (RDBMS) such as MySQL or Oracle. We try to illustrate it with in-memory databases (such as Pandas library).

tasks.title: Define an n-ary relation
Identify relational concepts in databases (tables, primary keys, foreign keys, composite keys)
Do simple selects and joins
Define support and confidence in association rules (such as item purchases)

links.title: Operate with relational operations

links.description: This subsection discusses advantages for each representation and what things can be computed for each one.

tasks.title: Manipulate relations with their matrix representation
Manipulate relations with their directed graph representation

links.title: Represent binary relations as matrices and directed graphs

videos.title: Matrix Representations of Relations and Properties

objectives: Prove or disprove that a relation has a given property (include function/mapping properties).
Use in-memory databases to illustrate relational algebra (select and join)
Compute support and confidence for item collections in an n-ary database
Transform relations from one representation to another.
Construct relations by their properties.
title: 2022-02-22 to 2022-02-26

links.description: The subsection introduces the concept of closure (as the “smallest” of all possible subsets with the given property). One particularly useful subtype of closure is the transitive closure.

tasks.title: Define transitive closure and some other closures.
Use and analyze Warshall Algorithm

links.title: Find and use relation closures

links.description: This subsection discusses a very useful subspecies of relations – equivalence relations; and how they can be used to structure the set where they are defined.

tasks.title: Verify that a relation is an equivalence relation
Show the equivalence classes created by an equivalence relation

links.title: Use equivalence relations for set partitions

links.description: This subsection addresses a set with a common relation – that of a partial order (which is also reflexive, antisymmetric and transitive, but two elements may also be incomparable).

tasks.title: Introduce partially ordered set and related concepts (well ordered, totally ordered sets).
Introduce various types of lexicographic orderings (also reverse ordering, shortlist ordering)
Manipulate Hasse diagrams and transitive closures on them
Define lattices and the concepts of least upper bound and greatest lower bound.
Describe topological sorting

links.title: Prove and use statements about partially ordered sets

videos.title: What is a Partial Order Relation?

objectives: Transform Hasse diagram into its transitive closure and back again
Construct other types of closures (reflexive and symmetric closure)
Use equivalence relations in various problems
Define setoids as sets of equivalence classes with their canonical representatives
Define and use the total order relations.
Define and use the partial order relations
Run an algorithm on the ordered sets, do topological sorting
title: 2022-03-01 to 2022-03-05

links.title: Use combinatorics

links.description: The subsection shows easy principles to evaluate the number of various selections (and they generalize lots of specialized formulas)

tasks.title: Use the product rule and the sum rule
Use the subtraction rule and the division rule
Use the principle of inclusion-exclusion

links.title: Count the number of elements in ordered or unordered selections with or without repetition.

links.description: Subsection discusses a simple idea of a proof by contradiction also known as the Dirichlet principle (if there are n+1 objects and n boxes, then at least one box should have at least 2 objects) and some variants of this.

tasks.title: Use the simplest form of Pigeonhole principle
Use the generalizations of the Pigeonhole principle
Use Pigeonhole principle in number theory

links.title: Use the Pigeonhole principle

links.description: This is similar to 6.1, but we revisit the material and show how to compute some well-known selections (permutations and combinations with or without repetition).

tasks.title: Count permutations without repetitions
Count combinations without repetitions

links.title: Count permutations and combinations

links.description: This is similar to 6.1, but we revisit the material and show how to compute some well-known selections (permutations and combinations with or without repetition).

tasks.title: Build pascal’s triangle and use it to view various sums of binomial coefficients
Use Newton’s binomial formula
Use multinomial formula
Prove various identities with binomial coefficients.

links.title: Define binomial coefficients

links.description: This subsection is a summary that discusses how the symmetry in a problem (distinguishable or indistinguishable objects, their order, their repetitions) affect the total count.

tasks.title: Count permutations with repetitions
Count combinations with repetitions
Count other selections with symmetry (distinguishable order, circular direction, etc.)

links.title: Compute and use generalized permutations and combinations

objectives: Build the “decision trees” to compute combinations (using addition and multiplication rule)
Build the clusterings on sets to compute combinations (using subtraction and division rule)
Use Pigeonhole principle for number theory facts (full system of remainders and so on)
Use binomial coefficients in polynomial algebra and related counting tasks
Use counting formulas for combinatorial problems with various types of symmetries (ordered vs. unordered selections; ordered in a cycle; ordered in an unoriented cycle; etc.)
title: 2022-03-08 to 2022-03-12

links.title: Compute and manipulate discrete probabilities

links.description: This subsection introduces the simplest notion of probability for discrete (i.e. countable) events. Use assumptions that all elementary events have equal probabilities.

tasks.title: Define the classical definition of probability and event
Define union, intersection and comlement of events
Compute probability for some events and combinations of events
Analyze probabilistic “paradoxes” and surprises

links.title: Use the classical definition of probability

links.description: This chapter introduces all the fundamental concepts of discrete probabilities once they have been defined.

tasks.title: Add probabilities of elementary events in various combinations
Use the sum for pairwise disjoint events
Use the inclusion/exclusion principle for probabilities
Define and use conditional probabilities
Define and use independent events
Define Bernoulli distribution
Define Binomial distribution
Define and use the concept of random variable
Introduce and solve the Birthday problem (1st kind of waiting time)
Introduce other types of waiting times
Define probabilistic algorithms and probabilistic simulations

links.title: Introduce the basic concepts of the probability theory

videos.title: Random Variables and the Binomial Distribution

links.description: The subsection shows a very practical way to express unknown conditional probabilities using directly observable ones (which show the “opposite” conditional probabilities).

tasks.title: Formulate and prove Bayes’ Theorem
Formulate some variants and generalizations of Bayes’ Theorem
Show the applications of Bayes’ Theorem in text clusterization, spam filters and Data Leak Prevention

links.title: Apply Bayes’ theorem

links.description: There are many ways to summarize larger amounts of numeric data (including median, inter-quartile range, mode, etc.), but here we only deal with the two simplest measures. Expected value (also mean and expectation) is defined for a random variable and it expresses the location. Variance (dispersija) and its square root – standard deviation (standartnovirze) measure the variability of data – how far it goes from the mean value.

tasks.title: Define and compute the expected value of a random variable
Use the linearity of expected value and other properties
Apply the expected value to find average-case computational complexity.
Define the uniform distribution; find its expected value and variance
Define the Poisson distribution with parameters; find its expected value and variance
Define the geometric distribution and find its expected value (the 2nd type of waiting time)
Define Multinomial distributions and their parameters; find its expected value and variance
Define Hypergeometric distrubtions and their parameters; find its expected value and variance
Define independent set of random variables
Define the variance of a random variable and its standard deviation.
Formulate and prove Bienayame’s Formula
Formulate and prove Markov’s Inequality
Formulate and prove Chebyshev’s Inequality

links.title: Summarise data with expected value and variance

objectives: Use classic probability definitions to analyze combinatorial tasks
Use analytic methods and randomized experiments to analyze waiting times and similar word problems.
Use Bayes formula to compute conditional probabilities
Apply appropriate discrete distributions as models for real-life problems
Compute expected value and variance for random variables, use them to estimate probabilities of hitting an interval
title: 2022-03-15 to 2022-03-19

links.title: Obtain convenient expressions for various useful sequences and counting problems

links.description: The subsection shows how real-life problems can be converted into recurrent sequences; their definitions and closed formulas for these sequences (a closed formula is an explicit expression to compute the n-th member of a sequence without going through all the recurrent members preceding it.

tasks.title: Write recurrent relations for Hanoi tower and similar recursive processes
Write recurrent relations to count strings with certain properties
Define Catalan numbers and use their correspondence with counting hierarchy-like structures

links.title: Build recurrent relations for word problems

links.description: Homogeneous and nonhomogeneous linear recurrences have some general methods to solve them (characteristic equations that allow to determine, what part of the sequence grows like a geometric progression). Fibonacci series is the best known linear recurrence, but there are many others.

tasks.title: Use the characteristic equation for the case when all the roots are different.
Use the characteristic equation for the case when some roots are equal.
Use the characteristic equation for the case when there are complex roots
Solve linear nonhomogeneous relations

links.title: Solve linear recurrence relations

videos.title: Second Order Linear Homogeneous Recurrence Relations

links.description: Some practically important recurrences (and related algorithms) are based on subdividing task into parts (and then reassembling their solutions with some additional cost). There is a famous theorem that solves this recurrence (and has three subcases) – it is called Master’s Theorem.

tasks.title: Define and analyze the fast multiplication algorithm by Karatsuba
Define and analyze the fast matrix multiplication by Strassen
Define and analyze the merge-sort algorithm
Generalize the recurrence relations into Master theorem

links.title: Solve recurrences expressing divide-and-conquer algorithms

links.description: Some counting tasks are more easily solved for the intersections (not unions) of multiple sets. If we need to solve them for unions, it is possible to count the union by adding the counts for individual sets, then subracting (and/or subsequently adding) for those cases where something has been counted twice, three times, etc.

tasks.title: Explain inclusion-exclusion principle on a Venn diagram
Use inclusion-exclusion principle in word problems when intersection counts are known
Use inclusion-exclusion principle for number divisibility and Euler’s function

links.title: Apply inclusion-exclusion principle

objectives: Given a verbal description for a combinatorial problem, formulate the recurrence formula
Solve homogenous recurrent relations
Solve non-homogenous recurrent relations
Apply Master’s theorem for algorithm complexity
Apply inclusion-exclusion principle for hatcheck and similar problems
title: 2022-03-22 to 2022-03-26

links.title: Solve graph problems and use graphs to model other tasks

links.description: This subsection explains obvious and less obvious situations where graphs may provide an answer to combinatorial questions.

tasks.title: Explain graph concepts to communication and transport networks
Explain graph concepts in social networks, quotations, Web links, set intersections
Explain graph concepts in semantic Web
Explain graph concepts in tournaments
Explain directed graph concepts in precedence and dependency problems

links.title: Represnt word problem situations as graphs; define vertices and nodes for each case

links.description: The subsection focuses on identifying specific phenomena in graphs and also introduces additional restrictions on graphs (connected, bipartite, directed, planar, acyclic and so on) which lead to different parts of the theory.

readings.title: Graph Terminology and Special Tpes of Graphs

tasks.title: Define adjacency, neighborhood, the degree of a vertex, the Handshake theorem (the sum of all degrees in a graph)
Explain the differences for the same concepts in a directed graph
Introduce some special graphs – complete graphs \( K_n \), cycles \( C_n \), wheels \( W_n \) and \( n \)-dimensional cubes \( Q_n \).
Define bipartite graphs and matching concepts.
Prove and use Hall’s Marriage theorem.

links.title: Understand graph-related concepts and recognise them in concrete graphs

links.description: The subsection compares two approaches to store graphs (such as using them as input for programs), and when to use each one. It also discusses the “invariant” properties of graphs that do not depend on their representations -  isomorphic graphs may be considered equivalent – regardless of how they are represented and how their vertices are labeled.

tasks.title: Describe a graph using adjacency lists
Describe a graph using adjacency matrices
Define graph isomorphism problem and solve it in some particular cases

links.title: Use adjacency list and matrix representations of graphs.

links.description: The subsection defines connectivity for undirected and also directed graphs (included strong connectivity). It also shows how this is related to finding path or paths between given vertices.

tasks.title: Define paths in undirected graphs
Define connected components in an undirected graph
Define some other vertex and edge connectedness measures
Prove that two graphs are not isomorphic by looking at their paths or similar properties
Show how the concepts apply to directed graphs

links.title: Use the concepts of paths and connectivity

links.description: This subsection introduces computationally easy problem (Euler’s cycles) and computationally hard problem (Hamilton’s cycles) – and how each one of them may be used.

tasks.title: Define an Euler path in a graph
Define and prove the necessary and sufficient coefficient for an Euler path
Define the concept of a Hamiltonian path in a graph

links.title: Solve problems related to cycles in graphs.

objectives: Count varios graph elements from word problems and their representations
Construct paths in graphs defined in various ways; apply paths to answer questions about particular graphs
Use bipartite graphs and related concepts; find matchings and apply the Hall’s Marriage theorem
Find cycles in graph; both Euler and Hamilton ones.
title: 2022-03-29 to 2022-04-03

links.title: Identify tree concepts, traverse trees with DFS and BFS for simple applications

links.description: The root, inner nodes, leaves, ancestors and successors, paths, traversals – all these tree-related concepts are often needed when using hierarchies of various kinds. This subsection defines the concepts and also counts all such objects efficiently.

tasks.title: Define trees, inner nodes, leaves and related concepts
Rooted trees, parents, children, siblings, ascendants, descendants, height and depth.
Define full n-ary trees
Count (or prove bounds) for various elements in trees
Prove the logarithmic estimate for the depth of a full n-ary tree

links.title: Identify, list and count various objects in trees.

links.description: There are a few standard orders how to visit nodes in a tree (DFS is somewhat similar to visiting a labyrinth – and it also has three separate flavors). All these orders are important as they serve as building blocks to various algorithms.

tasks.title: Define BFS traversal in a tree
Define DFS preorder traversal
Define DFS inorder traversal
Define DFS post-order traversal
Use abstract syntax trees to get infix, prefix and postfix expressions

links.title: Define and use preorder, inorder and postorder traversals in a rooted tree

links.description: This section deals with MSTs – a concept applicable to an arbitrary connected graph with a tree (basically, which edges do we select from a given graph, so that it is a spanning tree (still connected graph, but does not contain any redundant  edges – there are no loops).

tasks.title: Define Minimum Spanning Trees
Construct the Spanning Trees obtained from the BFS or DFS traversals
Define the backtracking problem to search for a solution in a hierarchy

links.title: Define and construct MSTs (Minimum Spanning Trees)

objectives: Identify tree concepts; count them in trees defined in various ways
Navigate trees (show how to get from one node to another one).
Recognize rooted trees with additional limitations (full binary, n-ary)
Define and find Minimum Spanning Trees
title: 2022-04-06 to 2022-04-10
